name: Orion
description: Orion is a prominent constellation located on the celestial equator and visible throughout the world. It is one of the most conspicuous and recognizable constellations in the night sky.
mythology: In Greek mythology, Orion was a supernaturally strong hunter. He was placed in the stars by Zeus after his death.

name: Ursa Major
description: Ursa Major is visible throughout the year from most of the northern hemisphere. Its seven brightest stars form the Big Dipper asterism.
mythology: In Greek mythology, it represents Callisto, a nymph turned into a bear by Hera.

name: Ursa Minor
description: Ursa Minor contains the Little Dipper asterism. Polaris, the North Star, is located at the end of the dipper's handle.
mythology: Often associated with Arcas, the son of Callisto, who was transformed into a bear.

name: Cassiopeia
description: Cassiopeia is easily recognizable due to its distinctive 'W' shape, formed by five bright stars.
mythology: Named after the vain queen Cassiopeia in Greek mythology, who boasted about her unrivaled beauty.

name: Scorpius
description: Scorpius is a large constellation located in the southern hemisphere near the center of the Milky Way.
mythology: Represents the scorpion that stung Orion the Hunter in Greek mythology.

name: Sagittarius
description: Sagittarius is commonly depicted as a centaur drawing a bow. It lies in the direction of the galactic center.
mythology: Often identified as a centaur, usually Chiron or Crotus, aiming an arrow at Antares, the heart of the scorpion.

name: Leo
description: Leo contains many bright stars and is one of the most easily recognizable constellations, resembling a crouching lion.
mythology: Represents the Nemean Lion killed by the mythical Greek hero Heracles as one of his twelve labors.

name: Taurus
description: Taurus is a large and prominent constellation in the northern hemisphere's winter sky.
mythology: Associated with Zeus, who adopted the shape of a bull in order to abduct Europa.

name: Gemini
description: Gemini is dominated by its two brightest stars, Castor and Pollux, which represent the heads of the twins.
mythology: Represents the twins Castor and Pollux (Polydeuces) in Greek mythology.

name: Andromeda
description: Andromeda is located north of the celestial equator. It contains the Andromeda Galaxy, the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way.
mythology: Named after Andromeda, the daughter of Cassiopeia, who was chained to a rock to be eaten by the sea monster Cetus.

name: Cygnus
description: Cygnus is recognizable for the Northern Cross asterism. It lies on the plane of the Milky Way.
mythology: Represents a swan. Several different myths are associated with the swan, often involving Zeus or Orpheus.

name: Lyra
description: Lyra is a small constellation. Its brightest star, Vega, is one of the brightest stars in the night sky and part of the Summer Triangle.
mythology: Represents the lyre of Orpheus, the musician and poet in Greek mythology.

name: Crux
description: Crux, or the Southern Cross, is the smallest of all the 88 modern constellations but is one of the most distinctive.
mythology: Important in the navigation and folklore of many southern hemisphere cultures.

name: Aquarius
description: Aquarius is a faint constellation in the zodiac, situated between Capricornus and Pisces.
mythology: Represents Ganymede, a beautiful Phrygian youth who was snatched up by Zeus to become the cup-bearer of the gods.

name: Aries
description: Aries is a mid-size constellation in the northern hemisphere.
mythology: Represents the ram whose Golden Fleece was sought by Jason and the Argonauts.

name: Virgo
description: Virgo is the largest constellation in the zodiac and the second-largest constellation overall.
mythology: Associated with Dike, the goddess of justice, or Demeter, the goddess of the harvest.
